ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Thermal kinetics and short range order parameters of Se80X20 (X = Te, Sb) binary glasses

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Physics Department, Rabigh College of Science and Arts

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Bulk Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses were prepared using the melt–quench technique. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) curves measured at different heating rates (5 K/min≤α≤50 K/min) and X-ray diffraction (XRD) are used to characterize the as-quenched specimens. Based on the obtained results, the activation energy of glass transition and the activation energy of crystallization (E g, E c) of the Se80Te20 glass are (137.5, 105.1 kJ/mol) higher than the corresponding values of the Se80Sb20 glass (106.8, 71.2 kJ/mol). An integer n value (n=2) of the Se80Te20 glass indicates that only one crystallization mechanism is occurring while a non-integer exponent (n=1.79) in the Se80Sb20 glass means that two mechanisms are working simultaneously during the amorphous–crystalline transformations. The total structure factor, S(K), indicates the presence of the short-range order (SRO) and the absence of the medium-range order (MRO) inside the as-quenched alloys. In an opposite way to the activation energies, the values of the first peak position and the total coordination number (r 1, η 1), obtained from a Gaussian fit of the radial distribution function, of the Se80Te20 glass are (2.42 nm, 1.99 atom) lower than the corresponding values (2.55 nm, 2.36 atom) of the Se80Sb20 specimens.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Because of their various applications in different fields of electronics, chalcogenide glasses have gained considerable attention. The structural changes resulting from the amorphous–crystalline transformations are responsible for wide varieties of the optical and electrical properties of these materials. The crystallization process can be interpreted in terms of several theoretical models [1–3]. Studies of the amorphous–crystalline mechanism of a glass upon heating can be performed in several different ways. In calorimetric measurements, two basic methods can be used, isothermal and non-isothermal. In the isothermal method, the sample is brought quickly to a temperature above the glass transition temperature (T g) and the heat evolved during the crystallization process at a constant temperature is recorded as a function of time (t). In the non-isothermal method, the sample is heated from room temperature generally at a fixed heating rate (α) and heat evolved is recorded as a function of temperature or time. A disadvantage of the isothermal method is the impossibility of reaching a test temperature instantaneously and, during the time which the system needs to stabilize, no measurements are possible. However, the non-isothermal method does not have this drawback [4].

Binary Se–Te alloys are promising materials for many electronic devices based on the amorphous–crystalline transformations [5]. It was found that the corrosion stability of the Se–Te alloy is much improved in comparison with that of the constituent elements. The crystallization behavior of a glass is necessary to determine the suitable operating temperature range for a specific technological application. The effect of Sb addition on the crystallization kinetics of the binary Se–Te glasses was studied by Mehra et al. [6]. From the compositional dependence of the glass transition temperature, they found that a small amount of Sb (≤4 at %) leads to an increase in the chain length of Se–Te, whereas further increase in Sb content increases the number of Se–Te chains in the alloys.

The physical properties of materials are significantly dependent on their atomic structure, so measurements of the experimental data related to structure are fundamental to material science. For crystalline materials, numerous methods were developed for producing or refining models of the crystal structure based on the experimental data. However, non-crystalline materials are of equal, if not greater, technological importance, yet understanding of their structure is still relatively primitive and few methods of structural modeling have been developed. Chalcogenide glasses present a great potential for applications in technological devices, such as optical fibers, memory materials and switching devices, but their use is limited due to several factors. One of them is the difficulty in obtaining information about atomic structures, which define the short-range order (SRO) and the intermediate-range order (IRO) of the alloy. The structures of amorphous materials have been extensively studied by several experimental techniques like X-ray diffraction [7–9], neutron diffraction [10, 11] and Raman scattering [12].

In the present work, studies of the crystallization kinetics and structural correlations of the specially made Se80Te20, Se80Sb20 glasses are carried out using the differential scanning calorimetry and X-ray diffraction techniques.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para: Bulk Se80Te20, Se80Sb20 glasses were prepared using the melt–quench technique. High-purity (5N) Se, Te and Sb elements are weighed in atomic proportions and sealed in evacuated (10−5 Torr) quartz ampoules. The sealed ampoules are inserted into a controlled programmable muffle furnace and heated with a constant rate of 4 K/min up to 1200 K. The furnace temperature is fixed at the maximum value for 12 h with frequent rocking to ensure homogeneity of the melt. To obtain the glassy state of the studied specimens, the ampoules are subsequently dropped in iced water with a quenching rate lying in the range 30–40 K/s.

Thermal behavior was investigated using a Shimadzu DSC-60 differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) under dry nitrogen supplied at a flow rate of 35 ml/min. Thermograms are recorded as the temperature is increased uniformly at different heating (5 K/min≤α≤50 K/min) rates. The characteristic temperatures of the investigated glasses are determined using the microprocessor of the thermal analyzer with temperature precision ±0.1 K. A best fit of the results is made using the least-square method. Then, the arithmetic means as well as the standard deviations are used for calculation of the crystallization kinetics of the investigated alloys.

The glassy nature of the quenched alloys was confirmed by the X-ray diffraction (XRD) technique. The X-ray experiment was done using a Philips (PW-1710) diffractometer. XRD patterns were recorded using a graphite monochromator and a copper radiation source (λ=1.5418 Å) with a scanning speed of 0.04∘/min. The experiment was done in the scattering angle range 4°≤2θ≤115° in steps of 0.1°, which corresponds to the K-vector range 0.284 Å−1≤K≤6.874 Å−1.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
Typical DSC curves of the investigated Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses measured at a constant heating rate of 15 K/min are shown in Fig. 1. For both glasses, three characteristic phenomena are clear in the figure. T g represents the glass transition temperature and T o is the onset temperature of crystallization of the studied specimen. The last characteristic T p gives the peak temperature of crystallization. These specific temperatures T g, T o and T p are determined, as said before, using the microprocessor of the thermal analyzer with temperature precision ±0.1 K. DSC curves measured at different heating rates (5 K/min≤α≤50 K/min) have shown nearly the same attitude as those shown in Fig. 1 except for an increase in the characteristic temperatures with increasing heating rate. One can notice that the temperature difference (T o−T g) in the case of the Se80Sb20 specimen is greater than that of the Se80Te20 alloy, which means that the former alloy has higher glass rigidity than the latter one. The following two sections (Sects. 3.1 and 3.2) are devoted to find the thermal kinetic parameters while the last section (Sect. 3.3) characterizes the structural correlations of the investigated glasses.
Fig. 1
DSC curves of the Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses measured at a constant heating rate of 15 K/min

Section2.Heading: Glass transition
Section2.Para:
Two approaches are used to analyze the heating rate dependence of the glass transition temperature. It has been widely observed that the heating rate dependence of T g follows Lasocka’s relationship [13] 1
$$ T_{\mathrm{g}} = a + b \ln \alpha, $$ where a and b are constants for a given composition. Figure 2 shows straight T g versus lnα lines for the studied glasses. It is evident from the figure that the experimental points can be fitted, with correlation coefficient=0.992, to the above equation. The constants a and b, calculated using the least-square fit, are given in Table 1. In the literature [14], Mehta et al. have pointed out that the constant b is sensitive to quenching rate of the melt, a result which indicates that the physical significance of b is related to the nature of the structural relaxation within the glass transition region. Since the studied glasses were prepared using nearly the same quenching rate, only the chemical composition could be responsible for getting two different b values.
Fig. 2
Dependence of the glass transition temperature (T g) on heating rate of the studied Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses

In the second approach, which is based on the free volume model of glass transition, Ruitenberg [15] stated that the activation energy of glass transition (E g) can be obtained using the well-known Kissinger method. Accordingly, the value of E g is given from applying the following relation: 2
$$ \ln \bigl( {\alpha} / {T_{\mathrm{g}}^{2}} \bigr) = - {E_{\mathrm{g}}} / R T_{\mathrm{g}} + \mathit{Constant}. $$ Plotting the
$\ln (\alpha /T_{\mathrm{g}}^{2})$ versus 1/T g relation should give a straight line with slope equal to the activation energy of glass transition. The values of E g obtained from Fig. 3a for the Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses are 134.7±0.5 and 104.3±0.5 kJ/mol, respectively. Since the variation of
$1/T_{\mathrm{g}}^{2}$ with lnα is much lower than that of 1/T g with lnα, Moynihan et al. [16] have simplified the above relation to 3
$$ \ln \alpha =\ - {E_{\mathrm{g}}} / R T_{\mathrm{g}} + \mathit{Constant}. $$ Straight lnα versus 1/T g plots for the investigated Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses are shown in Fig. 3b. From the slopes of the straight lines, the activation energies of the glass transition are calculated. The E g values listed in Table 1 for the Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses are 140.4±0.5 and 109.3±0.5 kJ/mol, respectively. It is clear that the activation energies given from the simplified equation are higher than those obtained from the Kissinger relation.
Fig. 3
(a)
$\ln ( \alpha / T_{\mathrm{g}}^{2} )$ versus 1000/T g plots and (b) lnα versus 1000/T g plots for the Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses

Section2.Heading: Crystallization kinetics
Section2.Para:
DSC data have been analyzed to find the activation energy of amorphous–crystalline transformation (E c), the frequency factor (K o) and the Avrami exponent (n) of the studied samples. The theoretical basis for interpreting the DSC thermograms is provided by the formal theory developed by Johnson and Mehl [17] and Avrami [18–20], in which the crystallized fraction (x) can be expressed as a function of time (t) according to the following relation: 4
$$ x ( t ) =1- \exp \bigl[- ( Kt )^{n}\bigr], $$ where n is the Avrami exponent that depends upon the growth mechanism and the dimensionality of the glassy alloy. The relationship between the reaction rate constant (K) and the activation energy of crystallization (E c) is given by 5
$$ K= K_{\mathrm{o}} \exp (- {E_{\mathrm{c}}} / {RT)}, $$ where K o is the frequency factor.

The crystallized fraction is defined as x=A
T /A, where A is the total area of the exothermic peak between the onset temperature of crystallization (T o), where crystallization just begins, and the temperature (T f), where the crystallization is completed. At any temperature T, lying between T o and T f, the partial area (A
T ) of the exothermic peak between the temperature T o and T can be calculated. Considering all temperatures located inside the exothermic peak, the crystallized fractions as a function of temperature, x(T), are obtained. A plot of ln[−ln(1−χ)] versus 1/T data for the studied Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses, measured at different heating rates, shows a straight line over most of the temperature range; see Fig. 4. At high temperatures or in regions of large crystallized fractions, deviations from linearity to lower values could be expected. These deviations were attributed previously [1–3] to saturation of the nucleation sites in the final stages of crystallization. In the present article, the analysis is confined to the linear region which extends over a wide range of temperatures. The resulting straight lines are almost parallel to each other, as shown in Fig. 4.
Fig. 4
ln[−ln(1−x)] versus 1000/T plots measured at different heating rates for the (a) Se80Te20 glass and (b) Se80Sb20 glass

Based on the formal theory developed by Johnson, Mehl and Avrami (JMA), Afify [21] has succeeded in developing a method according to which the crystallization kinetics can be obtained precisely, a method which was previously discussed in more detail [22, 23]. Taking the logarithm of Eq. (4) gives 6
$$ \ln ( 1-x ) =-\ (Kt)^{n}. $$ Substituting for x=0.632 in the above equation makes its left-hand term equal to −1. Accordingly, Kt=1 whatever the value of n. This equality is correct for the time at which the crystallized fraction reaches the value 0.632, i.e. (K 0.632 t 0.632)=1, or 7
$$ K_{0.632} =1/ t_{0.632}, $$ which means that the inverse of the time at which the crystallized fraction reaches 0.632, at a constant heating rate, gives directly the value of K 0.632. A horizontal line passing through the point ln[−ln(1−χ)]=0 of Fig. 4 intercepts the different curves at specific temperatures T 0.632. Rewriting Eq. (5), at these specific points, gives 8
$$ K_{0.632} = K_{\mathrm{o}} \exp(- {E_{\mathrm{c}}} / {R T_{0.632} )}. $$ Figure 5 shows straight lnK 0.632 versus 1/T 0.632 plots for the investigated glasses. The values of E c and K o obtained from slope and intercept of the straight lines are listed in Table 2.
Fig. 5
lnK 0.632 versus 1000/T 0.632 plots for the studied Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses

In addition to the Afify method [21], different approaches have also been used to interpret the amorphous–crystalline transformations. The first approach is to evaluate the activation energy of crystallization (E c) from the dependence of the peak temperature of crystallization (T p) on the heating rate of the investigated sample. This relation was undertaken by Kissinger [2] through the following equation: 9
$$ \ln \bigl( {\alpha} / {T_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}} \bigr) = - {E_{\mathrm{c}}} / R T_{\mathrm{p}} + \mathit{Constant}. $$ According to this equation, a plot of
$\ln ( {\alpha} / {T_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}} )$ versus 1/T p should give a straight line with slope equal to E c/R. Figure 6a shows two straight lines for the investigated Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses and the obtained E c values are listed in Table 2. Because the variation of
${1} / {T_{\mathrm{p}}^{2}}$ with lnα is much lower than that of 1/T p with lnα, Moynihan et al. [16] have simplified Eq. (9) to 10
$$ \ln \alpha =\ - {E_{\mathrm{c}}} / R T_{\mathrm{p}} + \mathit{Constant}, $$ which means that plotting of the lnα versus 1/T p relation should also yield a straight line as shown in Fig. 6b. The average E c values, calculated from the preceding three Eqs. (8)–(10), of the investigated Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses are 105.1±0.5 and 71.7±0.4 kJ/mol, respectively. In a previous work [24], the E c value of the Se80Te20 glass was 112.5±0.5 kJ/mol, which is in good agreement with the present value. However, the average E c value (= 118±4 kJ/mol) obtained by Svoboda et al. [25] can be considered slightly higher than that of the present Se80Te20 glass.
Fig. 6
(a)
$\ln ( \alpha / T_{\mathrm{p}}^{2} )$ versus 1000/T p plots and (b) lnα versus 1000/T p plots for the Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses

Since the most widely used JMA model is derived for isothermal crystallization [17–20], an attempt has been made by Matusita et al. [26] to apply the JMA model for non-isothermal conditions. Based on their attempt, the crystallized fraction (x) in a glass heated at a constant rate (α) is related to the activation energy of crystallization (E c) by the following relation: 11
$$ \ln \bigl[ - \ln ( 1-x ) \bigr] = -n \ln\alpha +1.052 \frac{m E_{\mathrm{c}}}{RT} +\mathit{constant}, $$ where m and n are integer or half-integer numbers that depend upon the growth mechanism and dimensionality of the glassy alloy. For the as-prepared glasses containing no nuclei, m is equal to n−1, and for others containing a sufficiently large number of nuclei, which might occur due to annealing of the as-quenched glasses, m=n [3]. DSC measurements are made on the as-quenched specimens, which means that insufficient amounts of nuclei are present before running the thermal experiment, i.e. the value m=n−1 will be considered.

At a constant temperature and based on Eq. (11), ln[−ln(1−x)] increases linearly with increasing heating rate of the investigated specimen. Figure 7 shows straight ln[−ln(1−x)] versus lnα lines, taken at different constant temperatures, for the present glasses. The n values obtained from the slopes of the straight lines are listed in Table 3. The average n values for the Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses are 2.00±0.01 and 1.79±0.04, respectively. An integer n value (=2) for the Se80Te20 glass indicates that only one crystallization mechanism is responsible for the amorphous–crystalline process, a conclusion which was previously reported by Patia et al. [27] in the case of the Se85Te15 glass. However, n=1.79±0.04 means that two mechanisms are working simultaneously during crystallization of the Se80Sb20 glass [3].
Fig. 7
ln[−ln(1−x)] versus lnα plots measured at different temperatures for the (a) Se80Te20 glass and (b) Se80Sb20 glass

Section2.Heading: Structure correlations
Section2.Para:
The measured X-ray intensities have been corrected from background, absorption and polarization [28]. The corrected intensities were used to calculate the scattering vector dependence of the normalized coherent scattered intensity, I coh(K). According to the Faber–Ziman form [29], the total structure factor S(K) of a multiple-component system is obtained from the normalized coherent scattered intensity, I coh(K), through 12
$$ S ( K ) = \bigl[ I_{\mathrm{coh}} ( K ) - \bigl\langle f^{2} \bigr \rangle + \langle f \rangle^{2} \bigr] / \langle f \rangle^{2}, $$ where K(=(4π/λ)sinθ) is the scattering vector,
$\langle f \rangle^{2} = \sum_{i} ( x_{i} f_{i} )^{2},\langle f^{2} \rangle = \sum_{i} x_{i} f_{i}^{2}$ , x
i is the atomic fraction of element i and f
i is the atomic scattering factor. Figure 8 shows the total scattered intensity, S(K), for the investigated Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses. Absence of the first sharp diffraction peak, or the pre-peak, in the S(K) curves means that the investigated glasses have only a short-range order (SRO) and do not have a medium range order (MRO) structure. Fourier transformation of the S(K) data into real space [30–32] gives the reduced distribution function, G(r), as follows: 13
$$\begin{aligned} G ( r ) =&4\pi r \bigl[ \rho ( r ) - \rho_{\mathrm{o}} \bigr] \\ =&( {2} / {\pi) \int_{0}^{\infty} K \bigl[ S ( K ) -1 \bigr] \sin Kr.dK}, \end{aligned}$$ where ρ(r) is the local atomic density at a distance r and ρ o is the bulk atomic density. Due to the finite range of the experimental data, the integration limit in the above equation equals a finite value K max instead of infinity, which introduces termination errors into the real-space functions. The Lorch modification factor, M(K), was used to correct the termination errors [33, 34], as below: 14
$$\begin{aligned} G ( r ) =&4\pi r \bigl[ \rho ( r ) - \rho_{\mathrm{o}} \bigr] \\ =&( {2} / {\pi) \int_{0}^{K_{\max}} K \bigl[ S ( K ) -1 \bigr] M(K)\sin Kr.dK}. \end{aligned}$$
G(r) curves are calculated after one damping correction followed by Kaplow iterations as shown in Fig. 9. At short distances (r≤2 Å), G(r) should follow the density line (−4πrρ o), which is used as a quality check of the data, see Eq. (14). The values of ρ o determined from slopes of these straight portions of the investigated Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses are 0.0349 and 0.0358, respectively. These values are close to those calculated from the relation ρ o=N
A ∑ i
c
i
d
i /A
i , where d
i and A
i are the density and atomic weight of the element i, respectively. This coincidence between the experimental and the calculated ρ o values confirms the high quality of the as-quenched glasses. Although the atomic weight of Te (=127.6) is greater than that of Sb (=121.76), the bulk density of the Se80Te20 specimen is less than that of the Se80Sb20 glass, a conflict which can only be solved if one assumes that the number of neighbors in the latter composition is higher than that of the former glass.
Fig. 8
The total structure factor, S(K), versus scattering vector of the studied Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses
Fig. 9
The reduced distribution function, G(r), versus r of the studied Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses

The radial distribution function, defined as the number of atoms lying between r, r+dr from the center of any arbitrary atom, is given by 15
$$ \mathrm{RDF} ( r ) =4\pi r^{2} \rho ( r ) =rG ( r ) +\ 4\pi r^{2} \rho_{\mathrm{o}}. $$ The positions of the first and second peaks in RDF(r) represent the average values of the first- and second-nearest-neighbor distances r 1 and r 2, respectively. The area under the peak gives the corresponding coordination numbers. Figure 10 shows the radial distribution function, RDF(r), of the investigated Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses. Gaussian fits of the RDF(r) curves are useful to calculate the short range order parameters of the first and second coordination shells. Two well-resolved peaks resulting from Gaussian fits are shown in Fig. 10; see as an example the peak splitting occurring in the RDF(r) curve of the Se80Te20 glass. The first peak positions (r 1) of the investigated Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses are 2.42 and 2.55 nm, respectively. As said before, the area under the first resolved peaks gives the first coordination number (η 1). Accordingly, the first coordination numbers of the Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses are 1.99 and 2.36, respectively. The higher η 1 value of the latter composition in comparison with that of the former glass confirms our preceding assumption, which is based on the higher value of the bulk density (ρ o) of the Se80Sb20 composition.
Fig. 10
The radial distribution function, RDF(r), versus r of the studied Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) data measured at different heating rates were used to determine the thermal kinetics of the Se80Te20 and Se80Sb20 glasses. Based on the obtained results, the activation energy of glass transition and the activation energy of crystallization (E g, E c) of the Se80Te20 glass are (137.5, 105.1 kJ/mol) higher than the corresponding values of the Se80Sb20 glass (106.8, 71.2 kJ/mol). An integer n value (n=2) of the Se80Te20 glass indicates that only one crystallization mechanism is occurring while a non-integer exponent (n=1.79) in the Se80Sb20 glass means that two mechanisms are working simultaneously during the amorphous–crystalline transformations. The total structure factor, S(K), indicates the presence of the short-range order (SRO) and the absence of the medium-range order (MRO) inside the as-quenched alloys. In an opposite way to the activation energies, the values of the first peak position and the total coordination number (r 1, η 1), obtained from a Gaussian fit of the radial distribution function, of the Se80Te20 glass are (2.42 nm, 1.99 atom) lower than the corresponding values (2.55 nm, 2.36 atom) of the Se80Sb20 specimens.
